w:r.w:t: The Virtual Data System uses the concept of profiles to encapsulate configurations for various aspects of dealing with the Grid infrastructure. Profiles provide an abstract yet uniform interface to specify configuration options for various layers from planner behavior to remote environment settings. At various stages during the planning process, profiles may be added to the concretization of a job.
This document describes various types of profiles, levels of priorities for intersecting profiles, and how to specify profiles in different contexts.
All profiles are triples comprised of a namespace, a name or key, and a value. The namespace is a simple identifier. The key has only meaning within its namespace, and it
yet another identifier. There are no constraints on the contents of a value.
Profiles may be represented with different syntaxes in different context. However, each syntax will describe the underlying triple.

Each namespace refers to a different aspect of a job’s runtime settings. A profile’s representation in the concrete plan (e.g. the Condor submit files) depends its namespace. VDS supports the following namespaces for profiles:
permits remote environment variables to be set.
sets Condor configuration parameters for the submit file.
configures the behavior of planner components.
is used for site selection configuration.
namespace allows users to specify environment variables of remote jobs. Globus transports the environment variables, and ensure that they are set before the job starts.
The key used in conjunction with an
profile denotes the name of the environment variable. The value of the profile becomes the value of the remote environment variable.

Grid jobs usually only set a minimum of environment variables by virtue of Globus. You cannot compare the environment variables visible from an interactive login with those visible to a grid job. Thus, it often becomes necessary to set environment variables like LD_LIBRARY_PATH for remote jobs.
If you use any of the VDS worker tools like
, it becomes necessary to set VDS_HOME and GLOBUS_LOCATION even for jobs that run locally.
Use with auxiliary jobs on the
Use with auxiliary jobs on the
site. It will be set for remote jobs by the job manager.
Point this to $GLOBUS_LOCATION/lib, except you cannot use the dollar variable. You must use the full path. Applies to both, local and remote jobs that use Globus components.
Use with replica registration jobs on the
Again, you must use the full path instead of the dollar variable.
Set by Euryale to the site's shared application directory.
Set by Euryale to the site's shared data directory.
Set by Euryale to the site's shared VDT installation base.
Set by Euryale to the site's shared temporary space.
Set by Euryale to the worker node's temporary space..
Even though Condor and Globus both permit environment variable settings through their profiles, all remote environment variables must be set through the means of

profile namespace encapsulates Globus resource specification language (RSL) instructions. The RSL configures settings and behavior of the remote scheduling system. Some systems require queue name to schedule jobs, a project name for accounting purposes, or a run-time estimate to schedule jobs. The Globus RSL addresses all these issues.

namespace denotes the command name of an RLS instruction. The profile value becomes the RSL value. Even though Globus RSL is typically shown using parentheses around the instruction, the out pair of parentheses is not necessary in
shows some commonly used RSL instructions. For an authoritative list of all possible RSL instructions refer to the
the number of times an executable is started.
specifies how the job manager should start the remote job. While VDS defaults to
for remote Condor standard universe jobs.
the max cpu time for a single execution of a job.
the maximum memory in MB required for the job
the maximum time or walltime for a single execution of a job.
the maximum walltime for a single execution of a job.
the minumum amount of memory required for this job
associates an account with a job at the remote end.
schedules the job in a specific queue at the remote end.
Pegasus prevents the user from specifying certain RSL instructions as
profiles, because they are either automatically generated or can be overridden through some different means. For instance, if you need to specify remote environment settings,
shows RSL instructions which are not permissible:
VDL transformations and DAX specify arguments to jobs.
The site catalog and properties determine the remote working directory.
The transformation catalog determines the application path.
VDL transformations or DAX specify the remote stdin.
VDL transformations or DAX specify the remote stdout.
VDL transformations or DAX specify the remote stderr.
: Globus RLS instructions prohibited by VDS.
The Condor submit file controls every detail how and where a job is run. The
profiles permit to add or overwrite instructions in the Condor submit file.
namespace directly sets commands in the Condor submit file for a job the profile applies to. Keys in the
profile namespace denote the name of the Condor command. The profile value becomes the command's argument. All
lines in the Condor submit file.
Some of the common condor commands that a user may need to specify are listed below. For an authoritative list refer to the
. Note: The planners by default specify a lot of condor commands in the submit files depending upon the job, and where it is being run.
for compute jobs that require standard universe.
is the number of times job is released back to the queue if it goes to HOLD, e.g. due to Globus errors. VDS defaults to 3. Use the
property to assign a different value.
is the number of times a job is allowed to get into HOLD state before being removed from the queue. VDS default to 3.
Useful for Condor glide-ins to pin a job to a remote site.
Pegasus prevents the user from specifying certain Condor commands in
profiles, because they are automatically generated or can be overridden through some different means.
VDL transformations and DAX specify arguments to jobs.
The transformation catalog determines the application path.
The site selector and the site catalog determine the contact address for the Globus gatekeeper or service.
The planners determine the location of the Condor common log.
The site catalog and properties determine the local or remote working directory.

DAGMan is Condor's workflow manager. While planners generate most of DAGMan's configuration, it is possible to tweak certain job-related characteristics using
profile can be used to specify a DAGMan pre- or post-script.
Pre- and post-scripts execute on the submit machine. Both inherit the environment settings from the submit host when
launches all jobs except standard universe and MPI jobs. Kickstart tracks the execution of the job, and returns usage statistics for the job. A DAGMan post-script starts the VDS application
to determine, if the job succeeded. DAGMan receives the success indication as exit status from
If you need to run your own post-script, you have to take over the job success parsing. The planner is set up to pass the file name of the remote job's
, usually the output from kickstart, as sole argument to the post-script.
profile domain that are understood by Pegasus. Euryale does not understand
profiles at all. However, Euryale permits to set the retries using the
is the path to the pre-script. DAGMan executes the pre-script before it runs the job.
are command-line arguments for the pre-script, if any.
is the path to the post-script. DAGMan executes the post-script after a job finished. In the presence of a post-script, it is always run, regardless of the (visibility of the) remote exit status.
are command-line arguments for the post-script, if any.
is the number of times DAGMan retries the full job cycle from pre-script through post-script, if failure was detected.
profiles allow users to configure extra options to the planners that can be applied selectively to a job or a group of jobs. Site selectors may use a sub-set of
shows some of the useful configuration option Pegasus understands.
ets the remote initial dir for a Condor-G job. Overrides the work directory algorithm that uses the site catalog and properties.
Please refer to the Pegasus Clustering Guide. This option determines the total number of clusters per level. Jobs are evenly spread across clusters.
Please refer to the Pegasus Clustering Guide. This profile determines the number of jobs in each cluster. The number of clusters depends on the total number of jobs on the level.
ndicates the collapser executable that is used to run the clustered job on the remote site.
etermines the executable for launching a job. Possible values are
This option determines the maximum number of stage-in jobs for a remote site.
ags a job with an arbitrary group identifier. The group site selector makes use of the tag.
to change into the remote working directory. If false, runs the job in whichever directory the remote scheduling system chose for the job.
If true, tells Pegasus to explicitly transfer the proxy for transfer jobs to the remote site.
This is useful, when you want to use a full proxy at the remote end, instead of the limited proxy that is transferred by CondorG.
Allows the user to specify the arguments with which the transfer executable is invoked. However certain options are always generated
s the condor submit file style. If set to

submission to the local Condor pool

This Euryale profile tags a job's site to the grid it belongs to.
Euryale requires all jobs to provide a maximum run-time estimate. The estimate is translated into
Euryale encourages all jobs to provide a maximum disk requirement setting. It is not used yet due to limitations in the site catalog.
Profiles may enter the job-processing stream at various stages. Depending on the requirements and scope a profile is to apply, profiles can be associated at

Unfortunately, a different syntax applies to each level and context. This section shows the different profile sources and syntaxes. However, at the foundation of each profile lies the triple of namespace, key and value.

The user can associate profiles with logical transformations in VDL. Environment settings required by a job's application, or a maximum estimate on the run-time are examples for profiles at this stage.
The example below shows some Euryale-mandated profiles settings for a VDLt snippet:
TR asdf::preprocess:1.0( input a, output b[] ) {
Please note that VDL profiles also may refer to formal arguments and logical filenames. In VDLx, the settings of above transformation translate into profile elements:
We do not expect you to see VDLx, unless you are writing a VDL generator.
Once the abstract planner concretizes a job, it will copy the profile into the DAX for the job:
While we do not expect you to read or write the DAX format, it is good to know, how to follow a profile from VDL to DAX.

If it becomes necessary to limit the scope of a profile to a single site, these profiles should go into the site catalog. A profile in the site catalog applies to all jobs and all application run at the site. Commonly, site catalog profiles set environment settings like the LD_LIBRARY_PATH, Euryale's GridCat variables, or queue and project names.
Of the different profile namespaces, it does not make sense to use the
namespace, because the site selection ran by the time the site catalog is accessed.
Currently, there is no tool to manipulate the site catalog, e.g. by adding profiles. Modifying the site catalog requires that you load it into your editor.
The XML version of the site catalog uses the following syntax:
The XML schema requires that profiles are the first children of a pool element. If the element ordering is wrong, the XML parser will produce errors and warnings:
Note that the order is important in the above example. Profile elements should appear first in the pool elements. If the order is wrong, you would see a lot of SAX Parser errors and warnings.
The multi-line textual version of the site catalog uses the following syntax:
The order within the textual pool definition is not important. Profiles can appear anywhere:

Some profiles require a narrower scope than the site catalog offers. Some profiles only apply to certain applications on certain sites, or change with each application and site. Transformation-specific and CPU-specific environment variables, or job clustering profiles are good candidates. Such profiles are best specified in the transformation catalog.
Profiles associate with a physical transformation and site in the transformation catalog. The
version of the transformation catalog also permits the convenience of connecting a transformation with a profile.

tool is a convenient helper to associate profiles with transformation catalog entries. As benefit, the user does not have to worry about formats of profiles in the various transformation catalog instances.
The above example adds an environment variable
. The transformation catalog guide has more details on the usage of the
The have yet to be implemented, but are expected very soon. Please note that property-specified profiles fall into three categories of scope:
applicability only to jobs at one site, and
applicability only to certain transformations at one site.
This chapter will be expanded as the feature becomes available.
Irrespective of where the profiles are specified, eventually the profiles are associated with jobs.

Multiple sources may specify the same profile for the same job. For instance, VDL may specify an environment variable X. The site catalog may also specify an environment variable X for the chosen site. The transformation catalog may specify an environment variable X for the chosen site and application. When the job is concretized, these three conflicts need to be resolved.
VDS defines a priority ordering of profiles. The higher priority takes precedence (overwrites) a profile of a lower priority.
The support for level 1 does not exist, but is forthcoming. Currently, transformation catalog profiles have the highest priority.
The previous sections omitted some of the finer details for the sake of clarity. To understand some of the constraints that VDS imposes, it is required to look at the way profiles affect jobs.
namespace are translated to a semicolon-separated list of key-value pairs. The list becomes the argument for the Condor
command in the job's submit file.
Condor-G, in turn, will translate the
command for any remote job into Globus RSL
settings, and append them to any existing RSL syntax it generates. To permit proper mixing, all environment setting should solely use the
VDS profiles, and none of the Condor nor Globus environment settings.
starts a job, it may make use of environment variables in its executable and arguments setting. The Euryale-set environment variables are beneficial in this context.

setting in the job's submit file:
